title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: The former is only an earthwork now, but, its massive heights abundantly exemplify the formidable  character of ancient fortifications, and on its breezy slopes the long grass ripples in the wind, and myriads of buttercups  brighten the emerald meadow with a sheen of gold. Close by there is an old habitation called the Castle Inn ; and if you are in quest of a refuge from the ills and worries of conventional life, I know not where you could more certainly find it than in that quaint dwelling, — with all of Old Sarum for your pleasure ground, and with the distant spire of Salisbury cathedral,  towering noble and clear on the southern horizon, for your silent monitor, pointing up to heaven. In Amesbury once stood the monastery, dear to the lover of Tennyson's Idyls as the haven and last refuge of poor Guinevere, in her remorse

title: A journal of a residence ... in London; including excursions through various parts of England; and a short tour in France and Scotland; in the years 1823 and 1824
author: Wheaton, Nathaniel Sheldon.
snippet: This I followed, till I came in front of a high park wall, onwhich was inscribed the very comforting intelligence of" No passage here—man-traps and spring-guns set in thesepremises." After a variety of doublings and turnings, andby many a weary step, I at length reached the height of thebank, and sound my way to the Castle Inn, in a little hamletclose to the ruins.
